Experience: Andrew T. Campbell is a professor of computer science at Dartmouth College. His current research on digital health lies at the intersection of mobile computing, machine learning and behavioral health. Andrew develops mobile sensing systems for capturing, learning and interpreting people's surroundings, behaviors and networks (both social and speech networks). His vision is a world where mobile AI can accurately and passively assess a wide variety of challenging illnesses (e.g., depression) using machine learning and predictive analytics with the goal of delivering personalized interventions to keep people healthy.

Andrew is a leader in mobile computing and is well known for his early work on mobile sensing algorithms and systems [1-5].  He “pioneered applying machine learning across local devices and servers”​ (ACM SenSys Test of Time Award​ 2018 citation)​ to first infer human behavior (e.g., in-conversation, sitting, walking) on smartphones-- today every Apple and Android phone and wearable supports activity recognition. Before joining Dartmouth, he was a tenured associate professor of electrical engineering at Columbia University working on wireless networks. Prior to that, he spent ten years in the software industry leading the development of wireless packet networks and operating systems. During 2016-2017, he joined Google to work on cardiovascular health as a member of the Android group. He is currently a visiting research scientist at Verily.
Teaching and research in computational complexity theory and the theory of algorithms.

Experience: Adjunct Associate Professor of Biological Sciences

Proteins are smart molecules that are responsible for much of what living systems are capable of. My lab is developing accurate models that describe how and why natural proteins work, and then uses these models to design novel proteins for a variety of applications--from therapeutic discovery to nano-technology.

Proteins are molecules that encode much of a biological cell's functionality. My lab is interested in understanding the design principles underlying natural protein function on a quantitative, structure-based level. This is critical not only for gaining fundamental insight into biological processes, but also for exploring the rich functionality of proteins in practical engineering applications.
Protesign, Inc is a biotechnology firm that utilizes a novel technology platform to design custom protein molecules.
Education: Studied biological phenomena using physics-based models.

Experience: See splice-project.org.  The SPLICE mission is to develop new scientific insights and new engineering principles that enable people to live in a trustworthy Smart Home, one whose security they can understand and manage, and with strong mechanisms to protect their privacy.
I was pleased to be named to this endowed chair in summer 2020.

See thaw.org.  This NSF-funded project tackles many of the fundamental research challenges necessary to provide trustworthy information systems for health and wellness, as sensitive information and health-related tasks are increasingly pushed into mobile devices and cloud-based services. The interdisciplinary research team includes expertise from computer science, business, behavioral health, health policy, and healthcare information technology to enable the creation of health & wellness systems that can be trusted by individual citizens to protect their privacy and can be trusted by health professionals to ensure data integrity and security. Although these problems are motivated by a nationally important application domain (health and wellness), the solutions have applications far beyond that domain.
Conducted research on wireless networks (802.11) to compare analytical models with experimental results.
